editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.head: Remarkable OBSERVATIONS On the COMET, in the Year 1680.
As also on the Blazing-Star, now seen, this present Month of August, 1682.
div.p: I Shall not trouble my Self, nor Reader, with the many Opinions of the Ancients, concerning the Matter and Generation of Comets, but let him understand, that on Monday Night last, being August 14. there was a Comet seen about Nine a Clock at Night, about North and by West from London: Its Head was very large, much about the bigness of Venus in her Elongation. When it came to the North part of the Meridian, it had not above 18 degrees of Altitude. As to its Place, it was not far from the Right Paw of the Great Bear; and for its Longitude in the Ecliptick, it was near 25 degrees in Cancer, having of or near 30 degrees of North Latitude, by which means it will not Set. It hath also been seen on Tuesday Night, and Wednesday Night, by a great many; it hath also been seen on Saturday Night, Sunday Night, and Monday Night; at which time it hath got into the middle of Virgo, as near as I could judg by my Eye, for I had not Instruments about me to observe it; it is swift in Motion, and direct, and decreases in Declination; and its Tail points to the South-East, but is not above ten degrees in length. The Comet is increasing, and therefore may be seen, if the Weather prove fair, all Night long, by reason of its not setting. I advise all those that have convenient Instruments, to make good Observation of it, for I believe it hath but small Parallex.

As to the Astrological Judgment of it, we must consider its Place and Colour; Its being in Cancer, doth declare Wars and Devastations in the World, with abundance of Unhappiness towards Mankind, and more than Common Evils to befal them; either the Heir of some Kingdom, or Chief Governor thereof, shall resign to Death. It also doth declare great Inundation to befal those Places under Cancer: As for example, in the Year 1530, there was a Comet appeared in Cancer; in that Year, in the Low-Countries, there were no less than 404 Parishes drowned, with all their People and Cattle; also the Turks invaded Hungary. Therefore let Holland look to it, and secure their Banks against the strong South-West Winds, of which we shall have plenty the beginning of this Winter, and those very boisterous. This Comet comes to bring forward the Effect of the last, that did appear in the Year 1680. That Comet came for a Warning to Europe in general. Let those Countries which lie East, and South-East of England, beware, especially the East part of Germany, for they are threatned with a very great Invasion, and that from a mixt sort of People, (viz.) Turks and Christians, which shall over-run most part of Germany. Then Wo to all those of the Shaven-Order.

France, Thou art like to feel the smart of War; thou hast caused thy Neighbouring Nations to feel thy heavy Hand for these ten Years last past; Now thy Time is almost at an end, and God has ordained thy Kingdom to be a Prey to a Forreign People, as afore-said.
Holland, look to thy self, God is angry with thee; thou must suffer by another Inundation. Besides, I fear some other Calamity to befal thee, thou must have thy Laws changed.
I pray God bless Scotland from Calamity, I fear there will come Bad News from thence in a short Time; but in what Nature let Time declare.

The Land of Aries cannot be free from the Influence, both of this Comet, and the Last, neither of them as yet begin to operate. I pray God bless the City Gemini from another great Plague, which I fear will afflict it in the Year 1683. In which Year 'tis thought, the Mole will fall in the Coffin, ond the young Mole, and the old Lion, will contend for a Crown; but after two Battels, there will come a sort of People out of the Wood, and will pull a dead Man out of his Grave, which shall Head these People that came out of the Wood, and they, with the dead Man, shall end the Strife between the Mole and the Lion; and then there will be long Peace in the Land of Aries, and neither the Mole nor the Lion shall ever attain the Crown; they shall fight for it, but shall both die in the Action.

Spain, great hath been thy Cruelty to the poor Indians in America; God will pour down his Vials of Wrath upon thee, and thou shalt become a Prey to a great many Nations, and e're 1699, thou shalt be driven out of all the West-Indies, and thy People shall become very poor.

Italy, when I consider what Evils shall befal thee, it makes me to weep; for the Plague shall destroy a great many of thy People: But that's not all, for the Turk shall come even to the Gates of Rome, and shall destroy thy Country with Fire and Sword, and that before 1699.
Neither will that famous City of Venice escape the Hands of the Turks, but shall by them be laid waste, to the Grief of all Christendom.

Rome must have a Time of destruction by Fire as well as London, but will never come to be so well rebuilded; for the Triple Crown must fall in or near the Year 1699, and soon after shall the World have a general Peace, and the Turk turn Christian.

Many things more might be said from both these last Comets; but by reason I have not a Warrant to write them, I shall forbear, but shall give you such Rules, in a small piece, (almost ready for the Press, and will shortly be made publick) which I intend to intitle, Catastrophae Mundi; wherein shall be shewed, how to judg of the Conjunction of Saturn and Jupiter, and other Comets; the like as yet hath not been made publick to the World.
